description: Dive into "Capturing Pompeii: Timeless Photo Treasures" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing Pompeii: Timeless Photo Treasures

places.generalDescription: The Amphitheatre of Pompeii is a remarkable ancient Roman ruin that once held up to 20,000 spectators for gladiatorial combats and other performances. This historic site offers visitors a chance to step back in time and experience the reality of living in a Roman settlement. Built around 70 BC, it predates the Colosseum by over a century, making it the oldest known amphitheatre of its kind.

sources.snippet: The Amphitheatre in Pompeii is one of the oldest and best-preserved in the world. Used for sporting events and gladiatorial combat, it could hold 20,000 spectators in three sections: the front rows for prominent citizens, the middle for the middle class, and the highest (called summa) for the rest of the population. This impressive venue showcases advanced engineering and the social stratification of the ancient city.
sources.shortName: Pompeii - Top Attractions - blog

sources.snippet: Clear on the opposite end of Pompeii and following Via dell’Abbondanza is the Amphitheatre, which was built in on the outskirts of Pompeii. It’s well worth the walk as the Amphitheatre is the oldest building of its kind in the world. Like the Colosseum in Rome, gladiators had bloody battles with wild animals while some 20,000 spectators watched.
sources.shortName: The Do-It-Yourself Tour of Pompeii

sources.snippet: The amphitheatre is quite significant because it is the oldest among those known in the Roman world. The stands could hold up to 20,000 people, who would have come to watch all sorts of violent shows. It is on the outskirts of the city to help with the flow of the crowds.
sources.shortName: How to visit Pompeii in 2025: Complete guide

sources.snippet: Actually we wanted to visit the amphitheater at the other end of Pompeii, but our feet didn’t carry us that far. The area is really huge. For that, the Grand Theater is also quite impressive.
sources.shortName: Pompeii, Italy: What To See & The Most Important Spots

places.name: Amphitheatre of Pompeii

reviews.text: So much to see, you couldn't possibly do so all on one day. Having a local archeological guide who grew up in new Pompeii tour us the grounds allowed the group to gain a deeper understanding of the ancient city and the contributions from both the Greeks and Romans. Stunning and inspiring!

A great and humble experience, however you need to pick your time to visit. It is extremely super busy, understandably, with a humbling experience.

Tours are great but sometimes its better to go and do your own thing here so that you are not guided together as there are many tours here

Very nice tour,  very hot place with lots of walking.  There was one family with a wheelchair and a couple with strollers and they were obviously struggling.  The streets are original stones in which you can see the marks made by chariots,  I understand now why people who had disabilities were carried into the town squares.

places.generalDescription: The Archaeological Park of Pompeii is a remarkable site that preserves the remains of the ancient Roman city, which was buried under ash and lava during the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. The vastness of the excavated ruins showcases the impressive extent of Roman civilization frozen in time. Rediscovered in 1599, detailed archaeological investigations began two centuries later, revealing a wealth of historical treasures.

sources.snippet: Your best bet is to start in the Roman Seven quadrant, then Roman Eight, and then further back are the mummies,” said the cashier at the entrance, pointing to an itty-bitty portion of the huge map of Pompeii spread out before us. It was already half past three in the afternoon, the search for a parking lot before adventurous and actually every guidebook says: You will need a day to see Pompeii. I can only confirm this now!
sources.shortName: Pompeii, Italy: What To See & The Most Important Spots

sources.snippet: But perhaps there’s nowhere in history as famously annihilated as the lost Roman city of Pompeii. The story of Pompeii’s sudden doomsday demise has been romanticized in art for centuries and continues to ignite research and wonder the world over – nearly 2,000 years after the city was wiped off the Roman Empire’s map.
sources.shortName: Visiting Pompeii: Your Ultimate Guide to the Lost City

sources.snippet: In 79 AD somewhere around 20,000 Pompeians went about their daily lives giving nary a thought to the volcano they lived alongside. August 24th would change their lives forever. On that fateful day as Mt. Vesuvius spewed, though much of the city was destroyed, Pompeii was also buried under 20 feet of ash and pumice.
sources.shortName: The Do-It-Yourself Tour of Pompeii
Pompeii Tickets | Skip-the-Line, Guided Tours & Transfers
Roman Ruins: 15 Captivating Things To Do in Pompeii if You Love Exploring
Top 15 things to see at Pompeii

places.name: Archaeological Park of Pompeii

reviews.text:
I could go on for hours. So I will be succinct with the basics.

• Book a guided tour.
• Travel light.
• Bring water.

Honestly, booking a tour guide is the best thing to do. You will have no idea where you are because the place is huge and may get lost down the tight streets.

There is a place to get food/drinks/ice cream, etc. This is up some very steep stairs. And it's going to be very busy. The only toilets in the site are located here too. So be prepared.

Overall, go and experience this very special and ancient site. Touch the buildings, walk on the streets, and feel the history!

The beginning of our visit was quiet ( not much people -was there around 11am). It is very interesting even if you don't have a guide ( we bought only audio guides).After 2 hours of walking I discovered that more and more people are coming. After 3 hours of walking ( we wasn't able to see everything as it became too hot) we decided to come back to the hotel. Overall I really enjoyed the time in there.

We came on the first Sunday of the month, it's the day with free entry (but better double check that before making any plans!). Normally the cheapest ticket cost 18 euros. There was very very long queue- so better come early. But inside it wasn't too crowded, only in the areas close to the entrances.
Very interesting place- interesting story, special atmosphere. It's definitely worth visiting, reserve several hours, and make sure to take water and snacks with you!

places.generalDescription: Lupanare di Pompei, also known as the 'wolfs den,' is a significant site within the ruins of Pompeii. This Roman brothel, consisting of two levels with five small cells on each floor, offers a glimpse into the intimate side of Roman life. Each cell features a stone bed topped with a mat or cushion and an erotic fresco above the door, likely depicting the specialization of the prostitute working in that cell.

sources.snippet: The lupanare (lupanar) was the city's brothel, and is one of the most memorable sites within the ruins of Pompeii. It was a two-story complex, with five small cells on the ground floor and five upstairs. Each cell had a stone bed topped with a mat or cushion, and above the door of each cell was an erotic fresco that probably depicted the specialization of the prostitute that worked in each individual cell.
sources.shortName: Tickets, Tours, & Visitor Tips

sources.snippet: The Lupanar of Pompeii, also known as Lupanare Grande, is the largest of the city’s many brothels. Located east of the Forum, it features 10 small rooms where brick platforms topped with mattresses once served as beds. Some of the wall paintings at the Lupanar are sexual in nature, but it’s the graffiti that both the prostitutes and the clientele scrawled on the walls that most surprises visitors.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Fascinating Ruins in Pompeii, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: The Lupanar is one of the most memorable sites in the ruins of Pompeii. It was a brothel with two levels: five small rooms on the ground floor and five on the upper floor. Each room had a stone bed with a mat or pillow, and erotic frescoes were placed above the doors, likely depicting the prostitutes’ specialities.
sources.shortName: Pompeii - Top Attractions - blog

places.name: Lupanare di Pompei

reviews.text: The Lupanare di Pompei, or the Brothel of Pompeii, is a compelling site that offers a unique insight into the city's social fabric during ancient times. This well-preserved establishment features a series of small rooms, each with a stone bed, showcasing the practical design of a Roman brothel. The walls are adorned with vibrant frescoes that depict various erotic scenes, providing a glimpse into the attitudes toward sexuality and leisure in Pompeian society. As you navigate through the intimate spaces, you gain an understanding of the personal and transactional relationships that existed in this context. A visit to the Lupanare is both thought-provoking and revealing, presenting a candid picture of daily life in ancient Pompeii and contributing to the city's rich historical narrative.

Nothing special. Ruins like all the others, except this one used to trade in pleasure instead of wine jugs. Now it's just a few crumbling rooms with some small cheeky wall scenes – and that's all about it. Still, the queues outside can be absurd. Unless you're really into ancient brothels, you're not missing much. We luckily slipped in ahead – all in the name of historical research, of course. muhehehe :)

Waited years to see this place. Very interesting but because we were on an organised tour with a guide I had to walk at her pace which was too  fast resulting in me not being able to take everything in . Also the narrow streets were rammed with people and at some locations staff were constantly moving you on. Apparently 29,000 people once visited the site in one day.

places.address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: The House of the Faun is a remarkable 2nd-century Roman dwelling in Pompeii, Italy. It is the largest house in Pompeii and features a replica bronze statue of the Dancing Faun, as well as the famous mosaic of the Battle of Alexander. The ruins also hold preserved mosaics and offer a glimpse into ancient Roman life.

sources.snippet: The Casa del Fauno (House of the Faun) is one of the largest and most spectacular houses in Pompeii, covering around 3,000 square meters with areas dedicated to the villa's owners and other areas for the servants. The name comes from a bronze satyr statue in the impluvium (a small pool for gathering rain water), and the villa has a number of statues, frescoes, and mosaics. Among the most famous is the mosaic that depicts Alexander the Great battling Darius and the Persians at Issus, now displayed at the National Archaeological Museum in Naples.
sources.shortName: Tickets, Tours, & Visitor Tips

sources.snippet: This is Pompeii's grandest house and takes its name from the little bronze statue in the courtyard in the centre of the residence. It's also one of the best places in Pompeii for admiring mosaics, although some of the very best have been moved to the archaeological museum in Naples for safekeeping. The largest of the mosaics, measuring 3.2 x 5.5 metres, is made up of over a million perfectly positioned small tiles.
sources.shortName: How to travel by train from Rome to Pompeii | Day trip

sources.snippet: The House of the Faun was the biggest and most expensive house in Pompeii, which makes it a must-see attraction in Pompeii. The word “house” is actually a misnomer since it covers an entire city block at 32,000 square feet ( 3,000 square meters). The owner had so much money he actually had a mosaic built into the street in front of his house with the Latin word HAVE, which means “greetings!.
sources.shortName: 15 Things You Can’t Miss When Visiting Pompeii in 2024
Top 15 Things to See at Pompeii in 2025

sources.snippet: The largest of the private villas in Pompeii, the House of the Faun takes up an entire city block. It was in this massive structure that archeologists discovered some of Pompeii’s greatest artistic treasures, including the Alexander Mosaic, which depicts Alexander the Great taking up arms against Darius III of Persia. The house was named after another famous find, a bronze statue of a faun.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Fascinating Ruins in Pompeii, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: The House of the Faun was the biggest and most expensive house in Pompeii. The word “house” is actually a misnomer since it covers an entire city block at 32,000 sq ft ( 3,000 sq m). The owner had so much money he actually had a mosaic built into the street in front of his house with a Latin word ” HAVE” which means, greetings!
sources.shortName: Top 15 things to see at Pompeii

sources.snippet: This is one of the most famous houses in Pompeii because it is one of the largest and most opulent. You can see that straight away in the pillars and inlaid floor of the entrance. There are two atriums and two courtyards with private and entertaining rooms coming off them.
sources.shortName: How to visit Pompeii in 2025: Complete guide

sources.snippet: This is the biggest house in Pompeii and gets its name from the statue in the front courtyard. Built in the 2nd century BCE, there’s a large courtyard in the back where you can also find a very detailed mosaic of a battle scene.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Guide to Visiting Pompeii (Updated 2025)

sources.snippet: The House of the Faun (Casa del Fauno) is one of the largest and most spectacular residences in Pompeii. It covers about 3,000 square meters. Its name comes from a bronze statuette of a satyr placed in the impluvium.
sources.shortName: Pompeii - Top Attractions - blog

places.name: House of the Faun

reviews.text: The Casa del Fauno, or House of the Faun, is a splendid example of Pompeian opulence and artistry, captivating visitors with its grand scale and exquisite details. This luxurious residence features stunning frescoes, intricate mosaics, and a charming atrium, all centered around a striking statue of a faun, embodying the spirit of revelry and nature. The house's layout offers a glimpse into the lifestyles of Pompeii's elite, with spacious rooms designed for both intimate gatherings and extravagant celebrations. As you explore its beautifully preserved spaces, you can almost feel the pulse of ancient life and the whispers of tales told within these walls. A visit to the Casa del Fauno is a romantic stroll through history, where art and architecture beautifully intertwine to create an enchanting experience.

I visited the House of the Faun in Pompeii and was truly impressed. Everything is so beautiful and well preserved - the mosaics and architecture are stunning. Pompeii itself left a deep impression on me, and I highly recommend everyone to visit. It's amazing to walk through a city frozen in time since the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD.
Amazing house and beautiful garden, don't expect much from the statue as its very small but beautiful nonetheless.

places.generalDescription: The House of the Vettii is a well-known and luxurious residence in Pompeii, famous for its richly colored frescos and statues.

sources.snippet: Some aspects of the culture were distinctly erotic, including frequent use of the phallus as apotropaion or good-luck charm in various types of decoration.
sources.shortName: 30 Amazing pictures of Pompeii
Pompeii Map and Tourist Guide

places.name: Casa dei Vettii

reviews.text: The Casa dei Vettii, or House of the Vettii, is an exquisite example of Pompeian architecture, showcasing the opulence and cultural vibrancy of its time. This splendid residence features elaborate frescoes that depict mythological scenes and lavish ornamentation, reflecting the wealth of its former owners. The harmonious layout, including a stunning atrium and lush garden, invites visitors to envision the lively social gatherings that once took place within its walls. As you explore the intricately decorated rooms, you are transported into a world of ancient luxury and artistry, making the Casa dei Vettii a must-visit destination for anyone interested in the rich history of Pompeii. Each detail tells a story, revealing the intimate connection between art, culture, and daily life in this captivating ancient city.
One of the most beautiful house in Pompei. It's very interesting to see all the beautiful paintings. They are beautiful preserved. Take time to visit them!

One of the best houses I seen in Pompeii, love the walls paints, it's just magical how they survive so many years and they are so perfectly artistic. If I can I will copy those for my house. Just stunning

places.address: Vicolo dei Vetti, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Villa dei Misteri, a Roman villa dating back to the 2nd century BCE, is located at the northwestern edge of Pompeii. The villa boasts well-preserved and richly decorated frescoes that depict the initiation of a young bride into the mysteries of the cult of Dionysus. These vibrant frescoes, painted in glowing Pompeiian red, are found throughout many rooms, with the finest ones adorning the triclinium.

sources.snippet: Located outside Pompeii on the road that leads down to the city’s harbor is the well-preserved ruins of the Villa dei Misteri (Villa of the Mysteries). The Roman Villa features wonderfully preserved frescoes that appear to depict a woman being initiated into the forbidden cult of Dionysus, the god of decadence known as Bacchus to the Romans. The term “mysteries” refers to this secret initiation rite.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Fascinating Ruins in Pompeii, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: You’ll also pass by the Villa dei Misteri if you’re following this route, which is a project to cultivate grape vines and produce wine from the very spot where vines grew in Pompeii some 2000 years ago. Only 1700 bottles are produced and they are auctioned off, so you can’t purchase or taste this special wine unfortunately. But the vineyard set in the ruins is truly unique.
sources.shortName: The Do-It-Yourself Tour of Pompeii

sources.snippet: Translated as Villa of Mysteries, the name itself derives from a Fresco showing the initiation of a young girl into a                     ” Mystery” cult. To clarify, mystery rites were closely guarded secrets into a particular pagan cult where, as the name suggests, nobody outside of the cult would have any idea of what was going on.
sources.shortName: Top 15 things to see at Pompeii

sources.snippet: Translated as Villa of Mysteries, the name itself derives from a fresco showing the initiation of a young girl into a mystery cult. To clarify, mystery rites were closely guarded secrets in particular pagan cults where, as the name suggests, nobody outside the cult would have any idea of what was going on.
sources.shortName: 15 Things You Can’t Miss When Visiting Pompeii in 2024
Top 15 Things to See at Pompeii in 2025

sources.snippet: One of Pompeii’s hidden gems is Villa dei Misteri (Villa of the Mysteries). It’s a very famous building, but it’s often looked over during a visit, because it’s a villa that was built outside the city walls and that’s why it’s not included in a regular visit. Its interior frescoes are wonderful!
sources.shortName: Visiting Pompeii: Your Ultimate Guide to the Lost City

sources.snippet: The Campania Express will take you directly to the Pompei Scavi Villa Dei Misteri Train Station from the Naples Piazza Garibaldi Train Station or the Naples Porta Nolana Train Station for around 15 Euro. The trip takes around half an hour.
sources.shortName: Pompeii Map and Tourist Guide

places.name: Villa dei Misteri

reviews.text: I'm was so glad that I have paid extra to visit the villas just outside the perimeters of the archaelogical site of Pompei. The villa dei Misteri is one of the most amazing structures I have seen. The scale of it with all the different rooms and the colours on the frescoes it was worth the extra price.

Interesting but not as much as the hype had me expecting.  It's in a distant part of the archeological site, and walking on those ancient cobblestones is hazardous for the ankles.
From a historical perspective, I am glad to have visited.

From a young age, I've always wanted to visit pompeii and it didn't disappoint!

Sure, you can watch documentaries about pompeii, but being there allows you to feel the atmosphere and smell the herbs from the neighbouring fields! Villa de misteri was amazing. The artwork on the walls that survived the eruption are simply breathtaking!

I will share a few pictures of my experience, but I don't want to spoil it for you!

I would advise you to buy your tickets in advance, and i would also advise you to pay that little extra for an archaeologist tour guide.

Overall, it was an amazing experience and well worth the travel from the UK.

Oh, don't forget suncream, i did, and i was a lobster afterwards!

places.address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled within the ancient city of Pompeii, the Temple of Jupiter stands as a remarkable testament to Roman architecture and devotion. Dating back to the 2nd century BCE, this impressive structure features remnants of grand columns and fragments of a once-magnificent statue of Jupiter. The temple is strategically located near other significant sites like the Temple of Venus and the oldest Temple of Apollo, creating a rich tapestry of history in this archaeological wonderland.

sources.snippet: The last stop on the way back to the entrance is the Temple of Jupiter, at the north end of the Forum. It was the most important religious site in Pompeii, but at the time of the eruption it was still being restored after a previous earthquake. Nevertheless, the remaining columns are impressive.
sources.shortName: How to travel by train from Rome to Pompeii | Day trip

sources.snippet: The Temple of Jupiter is one of the iconic buildings of Pompeii – not just because of its scale but because Mount Vesuvius looms behind it. The temple dominates the northern part of the Forum and would once have had statues dedicated to Jupiter, Juno, and Minerva.
sources.shortName: How to visit Pompeii in 2025: Complete guide

sources.snippet: The Temple of Jupiter figures prominently in the landscape of Pompeii. Featured in the Forum with a view to Mount Vesuvius in the distance, the temple was placed in the center of Pompeii where citizens could worship their most important gods.
sources.shortName: Roman Ruins: 15 Captivating Things To Do in Pompeii if You Love Exploring

places.name: Temple of Jupiter

reviews.text: The Temple of Jupiter, or Tempio di Giove, is a striking architectural landmark in Pompeii, commanding attention with its majestic presence and historical significance. Dedicated to the king of the gods, this grand temple showcases magnificent Doric columns and beautifully preserved remnants of its intricate facade, offering a glimpse into the religious fervor of the ancient Pompeians. The temple's elevated position provides breathtaking views of the surrounding area, enhancing its aura of reverence and spirituality. As you explore this sacred site, you can almost feel the echoes of prayers and offerings that once filled the air, making it a poignant reminder of the deep cultural and religious roots that shaped Pompeii's identity. A visit to the Temple of Jupiter is an inspiring journey into the heart of ancient worship and divine majesty.

The Forum of Pompeii was the central public space in the ancient city of Pompeii. It had a temple dedicated to Jupiter and was filled with shops and market stalls where people traded and conducted business. Excavations at the site have uncovered artifacts that give us a glimpse into the daily life of the ancient Romans.
Right at the end of the forum. Cool to see the foundations of the temple that would have dominated the square.

places.address: Via degli Augustali, 12, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: The House of Menander, an impressive Roman mansion in Pompeii, provides a fascinating glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of its wealthy inhabitants. This beautifully excavated residence features a stunning colonnaded walkway that encircles a lush garden and showcases faded frescoes that tell stories from ancient times. Among its treasures are exquisite mosaics and remnants of a lavish bath complex, all reflecting the grandeur of elite Roman life.

sources.snippet: The House of Menander in Pompeii is one of the most well-known and richly decorated houses from the Roman period. Its name comes from frescoes depicting scenes from the life and works of the Greek playwright Menander. The house consists of numerous rooms decorated in various styles, ranging from luxurious salons to private apartments.
sources.shortName: Pompeii - Top Attractions - blog

places.name: House of Menander

reviews.text: The Casa del Menandro, or House of Menander, is a magnificent residence in Pompeii that stands out for its opulent architecture and stunning frescoes. Named after the famed playwright, this well-preserved home features an intricately designed atrium with an impressive peristyle garden, creating a serene atmosphere. The vivid wall paintings, depicting mythological scenes and everyday life, showcase the artistic excellence of the period. As you wander through the various rooms, you can appreciate the spacious layout and the attention to detail that reflects the lifestyle of its affluent inhabitants. A visit to the Casa del Menandro offers an enchanting glimpse into the opulence and cultural richness of ancient Pompeii, making it a highlight of any exploration of the city.

The garden and house here look so well preserved you'd almost think you're in an Italian suburb rather than Pompeii. But I'm exaggerating – you'll find ancient frescoes, including dogs biting a guy's backside (everyone's favorite!). There are some bones in a display case, an old cart in the backyard, and jars everywhere. The House of Menander was home to a wealthy Roman and shows how life used to be here – basically an ancient Airbnb. :)

This visit is absolutely worth it.

Pompeii stands as a testament to a moment frozen in time, offering visitors an unparalleled glimpse into Roman life at its peak, preserved under layers of volcanic ash and pumice from the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. The preservation of this ancient city is not just remarkable; it's almost miraculous, providing a vivid snapshot of daily life, architecture, and art from nearly two millennia ago.

One of the most striking aspects of Pompeii is the preservation of its public spaces, particularly the marble restaurants and cafeterias. These establishments, with their intricate mosaic floors and frescoed walls, still hold an air of sophistication and elegance. The counters, often made of marble and adorned with geometric designs or scenes from mythology, are still remarkably intact. The colors in the frescoes, from deep reds to vibrant greens, have survived with surprising clarity, illustrating the daily menu or the ambiance of dining in ancient Rome. It's astonishing to see these spaces where Romans once gathered for meals, now standing as silent witnesses to history.

The overall preservation of Pompeii is nothing short of extraordinary. Walking through the city, you're enveloped by the architectural details - from the grand amphitheater to the intimate private homes, each structure tells its own story. The plaster casts of the victims, capturing their final moments in chilling detail, add a layer of somber reality to the visit, bridging the gap between past and present in a way that is both educational and haunting.

The site's layout, with its wide streets, the Forum, and the numerous temples, allows you to traverse through time, imagining the hustle and bustle of Roman life. The bakeries with their mills, the public baths with their intricate hypocaust systems, and the numerous shops all contribute to a vivid reconstruction of urban living. However, this journey through time isn't just about beauty; it's also about confronting the tragedy that befell this city. The juxtaposition of life's vibrancy with the sudden, catastrophic end is a poignant reminder of the impermanence of human endeavors.

The efforts in conserving and restoring Pompeii have been commendable, ensuring that future generations can continue to learn from and appreciate this historical site. The meticulous work on stabilizing structures, protecting frescoes, and managing the site's environmental impact have paid off, making Pompeii not just a tourist destination but a living museum.

Visiting Pompeii is an experience that is both amazing and disturbing. It's amazing for the sheer beauty and the level of preservation that allows us to see with clarity the life of another era. Yet, it's disturbing when you reflect on the suddenness of the disaster that preserved it all. The site is a profound journey through history, where beauty meets tragedy, making it one of the most significant archaeological sites in the world.

Treat yourself to a mesmerising experience that will leave you in awe.

places.generalDescription: The Garden of the Fugitives, also known as the Garden of the Skeletons, is a former vineyard in Pompeii where 13 victims of Mount Vesuvius' eruption were found and cast in plaster. The site is named after these plaster casts, which depict the haunting last moments of the victims' lives. Over time, layers of ash and pumice preserved their bodies before they rotted away, leaving voids that were later filled with plaster to create these poignant displays.

sources.snippet: The Orto dei Fuggiaschi (Garden of the Fugitives) was an old quarter of the city that was converted to vineyards as Pompeii grew. The name pays tribute to the bodies of 13 victims of the eruption in 79 AD who were trying to escape through Porta Nocera before succumbing to the ashes and stone. Their remains were discovered using plaster casting during excavations in 1961-62 and 1973-74.
sources.shortName: Tickets, Tours, & Visitor Tips

sources.snippet: As you leave the house of Julia Felix and walk back towards the entrance, on your left you’ll see the famous Garden of the Fugitives. This is perhaps the best-known part of Pompeii – it's the final resting place for a group of people who didn't survive the eruption. Interestingly, recent DNA testing has revealed they are all members of the same family.
sources.shortName: How to travel by train from Rome to Pompeii | Day trip

sources.snippet: Located in the back of Pompeii, this old vineyard has preserved casts of people who didn’t make it out of the city alive. There are 13 bodies in the garden, frozen in a grotesque and agonizing tableau that reflects the horrible final moments of the city. It’s both incredibly interesting and unsettling at the same time.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Guide to Visiting Pompeii (Updated 2025)

places.name: Garden of the Fugitives

reviews.text: One of the most sad spots to visit when at Pompeii. I knew I'd see the outline of the people that perished, but it's the children that really get to you. It's very peaceful over here though, and quiet and beautiful. It's definitely a contemplative spot.

It's a fabulous place to visit. It's quite large bring a comfortable shoes because it will be a long walk. I think you can finish it within 3 to 5 hours but don't forget to get the audio guide at the gate. I think it will make your journey more fun

The solemnity associated to being in the presence of (yes they are plaster casts of Pompeii citizens that were caught in the eruption) is deeply felt. These people had no hope of rescue or safety and their lives are cut short in an instant in time. Looking at photographs does not do them justice, but to stand in their presence is akin to the memorials of the Twin Towers, Hiroshima or a Concentration Camp from WWII.
Recommend that you walk the streets of Pompeii and soak up the amazing work that has been done here to allow us to journey back 2000yrs in time to an actual Roman city, this is not a movie set…it is real! Save the Garden of fugitives until the end of your tour , it will bring the eruption and the loss into perspective.

places.address: Vicolo dei Fuggiaschi, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Praedia di Giulia Felice is a sprawling ancient complex dating back to the 1st century BC, making it one of the earliest residences discovered during excavations. This patrician villa boasts expansive gardens surrounding several residential buildings and thermal baths. Named after an inscription found on its facade, this site offers well-preserved villas such as the House of the Faun, Villa of Julia Felix, House of Menander, and Villa of the Mysteries.

sources.snippet: The Praedia di Giulia Felice is a large complex dating from the 1st century BC and was one of the first homes unearthed during excavations. This aristocratic villa has a large gardens surrounding a series of residential buildings and thermal baths. The name Giulia Felice was taken from an inscription painted on the facade after the earthquake of 62 AD (today displayed in Naples' National Archaeological Museum) in which the owner advertises that part of the property is for rent.
sources.shortName: Tickets, Tours, & Visitor Tips

places.name: Julia Felix's Villa

reviews.text: The Praedia di Giulia Felice is an intriguing and richly detailed site in Pompeii that showcases the lifestyle of a prosperous woman in ancient Rome. This well-preserved villa features a spacious layout with elegant rooms adorned with vibrant frescoes and mosaics, reflecting the artistic flair of the time. Notably, the extensive gardens and various rooms suggest a blend of domestic comfort and social engagement, highlighting the importance of hospitality in Roman culture. The site also reveals hints of the owner's wealth through elaborate design and decorations. A visit to Praedia di Giulia Felice offers a captivating insight into the daily life and social customs of Pompeii, allowing visitors to appreciate the intricate interplay of art, culture, and history in this remarkable ancient city.

A private villa with baths, a garden, and rooms for rent – Giulia Felice clearly knew how to make a profit even after a disaster. Her house is one of the first known examples of Roman entrepreneurial spirit, functioning partly as a public rental. It's a gorgeous showcase of Roman luxury, but also a reminder that even in ancient times, nothing came for free.

Serene oasis in ancient Pompeii! Praedia di Giulia Felice is a hidden gem, offering a tranquil escape from the bustling ruins. Stroll through the beautiful gardens, indulge in a rejuvenating spa experience, and soak up the history and charm of this archaeological site. A perfect blend of relaxation and culture. Worth the treck across the site to visit.

places.address: Piazza Bartolo Longo, 37, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Basilica in Pompeii is a remarkable 2nd-century-BC administrative center with stunning Corinthian colonnades and Ionic capitals. The area underwent extensive excavations between 1907 and the 1950s, leading to the discovery of significant structures like the Temple of Peace, comitium, Porta Marina street, amphitheater, Temple of Ceres, and more. This ancient town offers a unique opportunity to step back in time and experience Roman life firsthand.

sources.snippet: Don't be fooled by the name: in Roman times, a basilica was the most important public building in the city, used as a type of courtroom where the judge sat on a raised dais above the sides. It was also where commercial contracts were drawn up. The space, dating from the second century BC, resembled a covered forum with columns and could be used for civic, religious, and commercial functions in case of inclement weather.
sources.shortName: Tickets, Tours, & Visitor Tips

sources.snippet: The Basilica in Pompeii is one of the most important and impressive sites in the ancient city. Known for its beautiful architecture and historical significance, it was a central point of social, political, and legal life in Pompeii. Located on the western side of the Forum, it dates to the 2nd century BC, making it one of the oldest buildings in the city.
sources.shortName: Pompeii - Top Attractions - blog

sources.snippet: On the southern end of the Forum, the magnificent Basilica is in slightly better shape. This monumental Greek-style building is where matters of law and justice were hashed out. It’s the oldest-known Roman basilica, with architecture that has since become a mainstay of churches and neoclassical buildings around the world.
sources.shortName: Visiting Pompeii: Your Ultimate Guide to the Lost City

sources.snippet: This incredible building would have been used effectively as a court – where justice was administered and important business decisions were made. The judges would have sat at the bench on the western side and the walls were decorated with stucco like large blocks of marble.
sources.shortName: How to visit Pompeii in 2025: Complete guide

sources.snippet: The Basilica in Pompeii was used for business and for the administration of justice. It was located close to the Forum and the Temple of Apollo.
sources.shortName: Roman Ruins: 15 Captivating Things To Do in Pompeii if You Love Exploring
The Do-It-Yourself Tour of Pompeii

places.name: Basilica

reviews.text: One of the most beautiful, majestic and warm church I have visited to date. We were lucky to be there just as Sunday evening mass was ending and the organ was playing-wow. Quite full and attendees seemed very happy. A must visit in in Pompei.

The Basilica at Pompeii stands as an architectural marvel, embodying the grandeur of Roman civic life. This expansive structure, with its stunning columns and spacious aisles, served as a hub for legal proceedings and social gatherings, infusing the air with a sense of purpose and community. The intricate details of the remaining frescoes and the harmonious proportions of its design reflect the artistic mastery of the era. As you wander through, you're enveloped by a sense of history, imagining the vibrant discussions and bustling activity that once filled this revered space. The Basilica, with its regal presence, is a poignant reminder of the societal foundations that flourished before time stood still in Pompeii.

This impressive building was constructed between 120 and 78 BC and served as the center of legal and commercial life in the city. It was used for court hearings, business transactions, and public gatherings. The Basilica had a rectangular shape measuring approximately 55 × 24 meters and was divided into three naves by columns. At the rear, there was a tribunal podium where judges performed their duties. Interestingly, there were no stone steps leading to the tribunal, suggesting that access was provided by wooden stairs, which were removed after use to prevent potential conflicts with the accused .

places.address: Vicolo delle Terme, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: The House of the Tragic Poet, located in the western part of Pompeii, is a restored home known for its intricate decorations. The house boasts colorful frescoes and mosaics, with a particularly striking mosaic depicting actors backstage. This led experts to speculate that an esteemed poet or writer may have resided here. The name of the house comes from a mosaic portraying an actor preparing for a performance.

sources.snippet: Located in the far-west section of Pompeii, the House of the Tragic Poet is famed for its artful decoration, which includes frescoes and mosaics that are surprisingly grand for the home’s relatively small size. An elaborate floor mosaic depicting actors gathering backstage led archeologists to postulate that an important poet or writer might have lived here. Also notable are the large mythological creatures portrayed in the atrium’s frescoes.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Fascinating Ruins in Pompeii, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: This is another famous house but for a completely different reason. It is the small image of a dog at the front of the house that makes it interesting because it also comes with the words “Beware of the Dog”. Perhaps the ancient Romans of Pompeii weren’t so different to homeowners of today!
sources.shortName: How to visit Pompeii in 2025: Complete guide

sources.snippet: At the entrance to the House of the Tragic Poet (see above) there is a mosaic of a dog with letters, which was to act like a doormat, below it that says in Latin – Cave Canem- which translated means- Beware of the dog. This just goes to show you that we haven’t changed after 2,000 years.
sources.shortName: Top 15 things to see at Pompeii

sources.snippet: At the entrance to the House of the Tragic Poet (see above) there is a mosaic of a dog with letters, which was like a doormat. The letters read Cave Canem in Latin, which means “Beware of the dog”. This just goes to show, we haven’t changed much after 2,000 years.
sources.shortName: 15 Things You Can’t Miss When Visiting Pompeii in 2024
Top 15 Things to See at Pompeii in 2025

places.name: House of the Tragic Poet

reviews.text: The House of the Tragic Poet in Pompeii was named after a famous mosaic depicting a scene from a play by Euripides. The mosaic warns visitors with the phrase "Beware of the Dog." The house also contains other well-preserved frescoes and decorative elements.
Worth the visit for the "Cave Canem" sign (beware of the dog), though the frescoes inside are quite cool too
it was great, until some red head guy in a green suit with a purple tie poisoned my entire being while screaming something like purple haze!!!overall 10/10

places.address: Vicolo Della Fullonica, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy
